abstract: Facebook’s deal to acquire WhatsApp shows that competition has never been more intense between technology companies fighting for the same customers and wallets. | Hedge funds are dipping their toes in advertising thanks to recent changes in S.E.C. regulations. | Banker go-to GrubHub Seamless files for an I.P.O. | The Fed finds vitriol among Wall Street’s financiers.
snippet: Facebook’s deal to acquire WhatsApp shows that competition has never been more intense between technology companies fighting for the same customers and wallets. | Hedge funds are dipping their toes in advertising thanks to recent changes in S.E.C....
lead_paragraph: TECH’S NEW FEEDING FRENZY  |  As soon as Facebook announced on Wednesday that it would acquire WhatsApp, a text messaging start-up, for up to $19 billion, almost everyone asked the same question: Why? What it boils down to is Facebook’s fear of missing out (F.O.M.O., for you cool kids). “Today, with Google, Facebook and others all fighting for the same customers and wallets, the competition has never been more intense, and big companies have never had to act so quickly — and with such conviction — to avoid being left behind,” David Gelles writes in DealBook. But the deal has raised fears that, by valuing the number of users above revenue, Facebook is inflating another dot-com bubble.

abstract: BBVA’s acquisition of Simple increases the possibility that banks can find a way to mastermind their own technological disruption, writes Fiona Maharg-Bravo of Reuters Breakingviews.
snippet: BBVA’s acquisition of Simple increases the possibility that banks can find a way to mastermind their own technological disruption, writes Fiona Maharg-Bravo of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Francisco González, chairman of BBVA, recently said that banks needed to take on Amazon and Google or die. He aims to be one of the survivors.
